newsitem.title: GERMANY: Tietmeyer - G7 did not discuss use of intervention.
newsitem.headline: Tietmeyer - G7 did not discuss use of intervention.

text.p: German Bundesbank President Hans Tietmeyer said financial leaders from the Group of Seven (G7) nations did not discuss the using intervention in world currency markets at a meeting on Saturday.
But Tietmeyer said member nations would cooperate closely, if necessary.
"We will of course closely...cooperate, if necessary. What means are needed we will discuss then," Tietmeyer told Reuters Financial Television after the Berlin meeting.
Tietmeyer also said he did not expect any exaggerated movements in foreign exchange markets and that G7 central banks would not focus their policy to currency rates.
The U.S. Germany, Japan, France, Italy, Canada and Britain make up the G7.

Asked whether the current dollar level was good for German economic growth, Tietmeyer replied "it is not a question of a precise level. We have never commented specifically on that...but it is more or less in line."

In addition, Tietmeyer said Germany's record jobless level hit in January should not keep Germany from meeting criteria laid out in the Maastricht Treaty for membership in the planned single European currency slated to begin in January 1999.
Asked if the jobless situation affected Germany's chances of qualifying for EMU, Tietmeyer said "I do not think so."

Regarding Germany's efforts to get finances in order to meet EMU criteria, he said "they will try to hold it (the deficit) below (the three-percent level as stated in the Maastricht Treaty). It is not an easy task, but I hope they will succeed."
